title: 111_hr230
content: The Act titled "Housing Opportunity and Mortgage Equity Act of 2009" allows for affordable refinancing mortgages and new mortgages. The Housing Opportunity and Mortgage Equity Act of 2009 authorizes Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac to purchase and securitize qualified refinancing and new mortgages on single-family housing, following established policies and procedures by the Director of the Federal Housing Finance Agency. If a lender offers a mortgage for purchase, the enterprise must determine if it meets the requirements for a qualified mortgage. The Housing Opportunity and Mortgage Equity Act of 2009 allows Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac to purchase qualified refinancing and new mortgages on single-family housing. The enterprise must commit to purchasing mortgages that meet the qualified mortgage requirements. Lenders can receive advance commitments for the purchase of qualified mortgages. Qualified mortgages include qualified refinancing mortgages and qualified new mortgages. The mortgage must be for a one- to four-family dwelling, with the mortgagor occupying it as their principal residence. The loan amount must be used to pay off existing indebtedness on the same property. The mortgage for a one- to four-family dwelling must meet specific criteria, including being subject to a qualified refinancing mortgage, originating on or before January 1, 2008, having a fixed interest rate not exceeding 4.0 percent annually, a term to maturity of 30-40 years, and meeting underwriting standards set by the Director. The qualified new mortgage must meet underwriting standards set by the Director and have prepayment penalties waived. The principal loan amount must be used to purchase the property. The new mortgage must meet underwriting standards, have prepayment penalties waived, and be used to purchase the property. Each enterprise can establish exceptions to underwriting standards for qualified refinancing and new mortgages. Enterprises must set aside qualified mortgages for securitization. Securities based on mortgages purchased by enterprises can be issued and sold with approval from the Secretary of the Treasury. These securities can take the form of debt obligations or trust certificates and must have maturities and interest rates approved by the enterprise and the Secretary. They are considered exempt securities similar to those guaranteed by the United States. The Securities and Exchange Commission requires mortgages set aside to ensure timely principal and interest payments on securities issued. Each enterprise must disclose that the securities are not guaranteed by the United States. The Federal Reserve System will establish a credit facility. The Federal Reserve System will establish a credit facility to provide credit to enterprises at interest rates comparable to Treasury securities. The requirement for enterprises to purchase mortgages will not apply to any mortgages offered after December 31, 2010. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS. This Act defines the Director as the head of the Federal Housing Finance Agency, the Enterprise as the Federal National Mortgage Association and the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation, and the Secretary as the head of the Treasury.
